if there's one component I want to use a third party implementation of it would be this gosh-darn viewpager. I keep getting "activity has been destroyed" crash reports I can't reproduce, and in one of the three viewpagers in my app quickly navigating away from and back to the nested fragment with the viewpager leaves the second fragment blank, and there's no logs or errors or stackoverflow solutions that help.

And this app doesn't even rotate. That added even more headaches on apps with viewpagers in the past. </rant>

in the AOSP launcher3 code, there is a PagedView which is similar to the ViewPager, but a bit simpler (and View based rather than Fragment, though probably could work with fragments as well). i use it in place of ViewPagers, but I’m working on launcher code anyway. I don’t know if it’d actually be worth getting familiar with and using in place of them in a different code base.
i generally dislike fragments
fragments are ok, but the API behind them is sucky and buggy and wtf*cky
they’re an ok idea, like an independent view unit
but the implemetation is rather lazy and has it’s problems
*its
something about the API makes me feel it’s too low level or primitive or something. and lots of boilerplate to create the arguments as a bundle and then decode them
<http://dev.kentin.me/2015/06/01/the-new-permission-system-welcome-to-ios/>

attachments.title: The new permission system: Welcome to iOS
attachments.text: Recently, at the Google IO 2015, we have discovered a new permission system. There are some good points, and some are really really bad in terms of UX. What is it? Prior to M release (or Preview), users had to...
attachments.fallback: My Android Journey: The new permission system: Welcome to iOS

text: Freshly typed.
nice. this other article talks about permissions and how it affects legacy apps (target below M): <https://newcircle.com/s/post/1737/2015/05/31/the-new-android-m-permissions-model>
also wanted to share this one, it's mine and it's about the new design support library: <https://medium.com/android-bites/first-steps-with-the-design-support-library-8dcf06230ddd>
Nice article.:) going to tweet that one out
not sure if I prefer this new iOS approach to permissions, but it definitely makes more sense to the end user
i’m happy with the change, it makes it much easier to justify adding a feature that uses contacts or something when it’s not an essential part of the app
Maybe people will stop freaking out about facebook permissions

Damn, I misunderstood until I read the docs just now. If you have a camera app you can't even require that permission permanently at install time. I mean, it's a no brainer when a user opens your app, but I can't believe we're complicating this simple use case.

I really wish we could require permissions at install time still
<@U053Q5XP2>: Plenty of time for things to change before M is finalized

Ya, I have some mixed feelings about this new permissions model. As an Android end user, I'm happy to see the change. But as a developer, it sounds like this is going to give me even more edge cases to check.
I haven't looked too deeply, but if it's like iOS, you can ask for them at any time
So the first time they open the app, many iOS apps have a screen that's like "We use the camera cause we're a camera app and it's useless unless you accept the dialog shortly. Hit accept"
Then when they hit a progression button, the official dialog pops up
Devs use that initial screen to describe what they are going to use a permission for if it isn't readily obvious
It's a more difficult dev flow, but it's more respectful for the users. And users should be our #1 focus as mobile developers. Not ease of development
Or iOS would have very few developers. (objective-c joke)
#disclaimer iOS and Android dev

attachments.text: I'm seeing a weird issue using the CSS filter attribute in my WebView. I have a WebView as part of a ViewPager. That WebView has a filter CSS attribute with grayscale [it also has a corresponding

text: <@U053NFVP0>: That is something I always tell my devs... I really don't care how difficult the development is just to add something for the user... it's the user we are worried about, not how something is going to take an extra case in a switch

if we can't be rude and dismissive to ios people here then where can we? This is a safe space.
I highly recommend everyone listen to the M permissions talk on youtube. They're aware of popup fatigue and the like, and I sympathies with the balance they have to hit, but right now there's just too much for the common use case. They should optimize to promote transparency in app permissions so devs have to explain their usage because the threat of it being turned off is there. But currently it seems tuned like everything installed is probably malware.
Well there is always tradeoffs <@U0542GLTE> It's a balance between dev time and app usage. Analytics will help you make that trade off.
<@U053Q5XP2> I'm the lead android dev but I do a lot of iOS work as well. Always room to bash both platforms.
<@U053Q5XP2>: where do you propose dev's explain their usage?
<@U053Q5XP2>: You have a link to the M permission talk by any chance?

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f17qe9vZ8RM>

To be honest, because only power users and ios converts care about turning off permissions, I like the current ask on install for core features like camera with the ability to turn off at any time from the settings, with the ability to ask for more, like read contacts if you want to invite people. I'm not too confident on that opinion though, considering I am not the target audience for this feature.
